param.name: patterns
param.info: A list of entries describing regular expresions replacements. Replacements happens per word.

parameterizedescaper.info: Word wrapping. Works on plain/text, and wraps with newlines. Can be converted to HTML with a chained escaper.

param.name: ellipsis
param.info: Can be used to put those three dots ('...') at the end of a 'substringed' line.

parameterizedescaper.info: Wraps a text in paragraph (p) tags, unless it is empty or that textstarts with a p tag (in which case it is already wrapped). Use this for fields that contain HTML, but for which you are unsure if they have parahraph tags already

param.name: class
param.info: A class name to give to the paragraph tag.

parameterizedescaper.info: Replaces the words which are present as key in given resourcebundle with the values. Since resource bundles are localized, this gives a way to translate (mm:write is nearly fmt:message). E.g. mm:write escape="resourcebundle(org.mmbase.datatypes.resources.ordinals)" value="5".
Explores the request for the 'referer' http header. If this is from google, the google search words are highlighted in the text.
Encrypts or decrypts the given input using a cryptographic algorithm that is specified as a parameter.

param.name: key
param.info: The key used to encrypt the data. eg. AES uses a 128 bit key.

param.name: format
param.info: The in-/output format of the ecrypted data. 'hex'(default) or 'base64'

param.name: algorithm
param.info: The algorithm used for the encryption. eg. 'AES'(default), 'DES', 'Blowfish', etc.

info.p: Escapes the code between the tags you define.
This escaper enables the use of two different escapers in one piece of text. It was started to simplify the inclusion of a code snippet in html but can be used for other purposes as well.

You can specify the tags between which you wish to escape your text, the escaper to use and you can set an escaper for the rest of the text. It needs to be rewritten to support all escapers/transformers. It only supports the escapers p, pp, p-ommit-surrounding, pp-ommit-surrounding, inline, text/html and text/xml for now. All parameters may be ommitted then it defaults to <pre> and 'text/html'. Use it like f.e.:
<mm:import id="texttext"> This is an example: <% String foo = "bar"; %> </mm:import> <mm:escaper type="codesample" id="testsample" /> <mm:write referid="testtext" escape="testsample" />

param.name: escapecode
param.info: The escaper to use between the start- and closetag.

param.name: escaperest
param.info: The escaper to use on the rest of the text.

param.name: tags
param.info: Either XSS or NONE. XSS will strip all tags and attributes which may have been present in the HTML to try cross-site-scripting. NONE will strip all tags, and produce plain text.

param.name: addbrs
param.info: If true, then newlines are replaced by br-tags. This can be used to make better html from a kind of pseudo-html.

param.name: escapeamps
param.info: Html 4 entities are resolved. This indicated whether the remaining ampersands must be replaced with &. Default to false. But see also the 'toxml' escaper.

info.p: This filters HTML-4, and cleanes it up, so that it is valid XML. At the moment, like tagstrippers(XSS), with escapeamps is true.
Replaces groups of one and more newlines by one new line, and one or more space by one space. This spares bandwidth and makes the result better readable.
